data.title: macOS: Git commit with ⌘S saves foreground document before commit
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.0 (8b95971d8cccd3afd86b35d4a0e098c189294ff2, 2017-08-09T20:06:21.685Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.5.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
python|don|0.7.0



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open project versioned with Git
2. Modify and save some file, and stage it for commit
3. Modify (but do not save) some file, and keep its editor in the foreground
3. In the source control pane, enter a commit message and commit using ⌘S

The file that has been modified but not saved is saved when ⌘S is pressed, *and* the staged changes are committed. This is the most visible when the foreground file is an untitled document that hasn't been saved anywhere yet because it brings up the save dialog.

The expected behavior would be that ⌘S commits the staged changes but does not attempt to save the foreground editor.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Haven't tested, but given my very bare setup, almost certainly.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.0 (8b95971d8cccd3afd86b35d4a0e098c189294ff2, 2017-08-09T20:16:18.034Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
aurelia|Aur|0.3.4
nuget-reverse-package-search|jes|0.1.68
vscode-nuget-package-manager|jmr|1.1.4
docomment|k--|0.0.17
mssql|ms-|1.1.0
csharp|ms-|1.12.1
PowerShell|ms-|1.4.1
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.1.8
vscode-docker|Pet|0.0.16
shell-launcher|Tyr|0.1.3
sort-lines|Tyr|1.3.0



---

I am adding my own snippets to try to replace what exists in Visual Studio, as much as I can. **I would like a variable such as `TM_FILENAME_BASE`** that does not include any extensions, since that is the default class/etc name for many languages. Or better yet, the ability to apply regex replacement rules to the variables, such as `${TM_FILENAME,/^([A-Z])/\L$1/,/([a-z])([A-Z])/$1-\L$2/g,/\..*$//}`:

  * `TM_FILENAME` - start with the filename
  * Comma separated regex replacement rules
    * `/^([A-Z])/\L$1/` - if the first character is uppercase, replace it with lowercase
    * `/([a-z])([A-Z])/$1-\L$2/g` - replace all `xY` with `x-y`
    * `/\..*$//` - if the filename ends with an extension, remove it
  * Thus, `MyCustomElement.html` becomes `my-custom-element`

Bug in PHP syntax highlighting with comments
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.0 (8b95971d8cccd3afd86b35d4a0e098c189294ff2, 2017-08-09T20:09:15.006Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.8.0-58-generic
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
xml|Dot|1.9.2

prettify-json|moh|0.0.3
php-docblocker|nei|1.2.0
markdown-preview-enhanced|shd|0.2.5
---

With the latest update to VS Code we are running into issues with the code highlighting with comments.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Insert the following code and set the syntax as `PHP` and you will see that code highlighting is not working:
```
/**
 * echos test
 * @return void(nothing to see here)
 */
function test() {
    echo 'test';
}
```
2. Now if you put as space between `void` and `(nothing to see here)`, the code highlighting works.

I understand that this isn't really the correct way to do comments in docblocks, but this is a legacy codebase and it was working in the prior version. I don't think that these comments should stop it from highlighting the code anyways.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Upgrading to VSC 1.15 64-bit Made It Unresponsive
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro :: 10.0.15063 Build 15063

I upgrade VSC to the latest 64-bit version and from there the app became unresponsive. Task Manager showed that VSC was using 98%+ CPU and the memory usage for the multiple instances was very large (100s of MB and typically 1 GB as well).

I tried installing earlier versions and also went back to 32-bit, but the same problem occurred. So, I did a complete uninstall and deleted the %USERS%/.vscode folder, and then did a reinstall of the 1.15 64-bit. While running Task Manager, I installed one extension at a time. When I tried to open a .cs file, VSC installed C# extensions and then the CPU/memory usage went to extreme levels which caused VSC to lag. When I disabled the C# extension, CPU/memory usage went to an acceptable level.

So I uninstall the C# extension and I'm happily using VSC. I think that the OmniSharp extension was causing the problems.

data.title: C# auto attach to process
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.15
- OS Version: Windows 10

![vscode_01_with_notes](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22569741/29419853-f17d7914-8378-11e7-824f-6f948313edff.jpg)

I've Just noticed that when I try to attach to a DotNet Core process using `command:pickProcess`, VSCode does a good job by enumerating all system's processes with their details.

As you can see from the picture above, VSCode seems to have the possibility of auto selecting the correct process automatically without the user jumping and scrolling through all the processes available from  `command:pickProcess`

I have a small suggestion. Allow VSCode attach (in Launch.json) to have two new settings:

`
"processId":"${command:autoPickProcessWithPattern:${workspaceRoot}/bin/Debug/netcoreapp2.0/TopTen-Server.dll}",
`

VSCode will then lookup the string, and when it find a match, It will retrieve the pid and attach to it automatically.

That will also open another possibility for a feature that I greatly miss from Node.Js; auto re-attach on change when using "Watcher".
`
"restart" : "true"
`

data.title: python code folding looks stange
data.body:
Currently, according to https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/codebasics#_folding
> The folding regions are evaluated based on the indentation of lines. A folding region starts when a line has a smaller indent than one or more following lines, and ends when there is a line with the same or smaller indent.

This strategy makes the folding of python code very strange, cuz blank lines between functions and classed are folded inside, like:
```python
class SpanInfo:…
@singleton
class SpanUtility:…
# models


class Staff(AbstractUser):…
class School(models.Model):…
```
Originally, it was:
```python
class SpanInfo:
    def __init__(self, start_time, end_time):
        pass


@singleton
class SpanUtility:
    span_info = {}


# models


class Staff(AbstractUser):
    def __str__(self):
        return '#{} {}'.format(self.pk, self.username)


class School(models.Model):
    name = models.CharField(max_length=20)
    available = models.BooleanField(default=True)
```
I think a different folding strategy is needed, or APIs should be offered to extensions to handle languages like python.

---

data.title: SCM: Allow inline commands in the API
data.body:
Currently, SCM menus get populated using the generic menu declarative API, which has the following problems:

- The SCM menu contexts are specific to the SCM provider id. Thus, with the current `when` clause syntax, it's impossible to have commands appear on all `git` SCM providers, in a multi-provider story.
- Hard to understand what the arguments of those commands will actually be.
- Hard to use, cumbersome to get going.

This extends the API to support providing inline commands with the several SCM resources.

The idea is to also deprecate the `scm/*` menus, yet merge them with the inline commands for a few more releases.

- [x] Sketch up API changes
- [x] Implement the API changes
- [ ] Figure out how to have separators
- [ ] `console.warn` about the `scm/*` menu deprecation

data.title: Integrated terminal does not open to project root using WLS

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1 x64
- OS Version: Windows 10, WLS:  Ubuntu 16.04.3 LTS
- Terminal Used: zsh/oh-my-zsh
- Reproduces without extensions: Yes

**Description:**
I recently upgraded vscode to the x64 build, and shortly afterward I noticed that the integrated terminal was no longer opening to the project root.

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Open Folder/Project with or without .vscode workspace settings.
2. Open Integrated terminal 
3. Terminal opens to '~' instead of project root.

**PS:**
Not sure if this is relevant or not, but the projects i'm opening are stored on a separate drive from the OS install drive. I mention this because any attempt to use terminal.integrated.cwd to remedy the situation seems to default the the C: drive.

data.title: Autocomplete unbearably slow when using `jsconfig.json` at root level
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:07:25.676Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

**Problem**
Autocomplete is very slow in providing autocomplete suggestions (**+3 minutes!**). After trying to debug this problem I've found that the issue is only present when a `jsconfig.json` file is present. I guess it might be that the `jsconfig.json` is not picking up the `exclude` array as it should and therefor is scanning all the `node_modules` (around 700 MB). This problem also reproduces without extensions, after a full uninstall (including those extensions) and on a previous release (`x32 1.14.2`).

**Project structure**
```
| Workspace folder
|-> node_modules
|-> .jsconfig.json
|-> .gitignore

|-> app
  |-> node_modules
  |-> ... other files

|-> dashboard
  |-> node_modules
  |-> ... other files

|-> wizer-components
  |-> node_modules
  |-> ... other files
```

**The `jsconfig.json` at root level**
```
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "target": "ES6"
  },
  "exclude": ["node_modules", "**/node_modules"]
}
```

data.title: Unclear error message when discarding changes
data.body:
The angry hippo in #32405 does bring up a valid issue.

![img](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/240625/29264526-c8a1b354-80dd-11e7-82d7-76e7b0066998.png)

Normally, with say Git, "revert all changes" means:

* Revert all **tracked** files to their VCS version
* Leave all **untracked** files alone

I do believe that SVN works in similiar way, altho I haven't used it for a while so I might be wrong.

"Discard all changes" should either clarify that (probably with big sign **THIS WILL DELETE EVERY FILE THAT IS NOT IN VCS** and smaller one "and ones commited will be reverted to upstream), or do not touch untracked files at all

data.title: Feature request: setting the default state of the "Toggle Word Wrap" option
data.body: I use `"editor.wordWrap": "wordWrapColumn"` and `"editor.wordWrapColumn": 120` and that is perfect but I would love for files to not open with word-wrap applied. That's what the "Toggle Word Wrap" option is for. I only occasionally need to actually wrap the source code for better reading long-lines but, more often than not, I don't use the wrapping. Can an option like `"editor.toggleWordWrap": true/fase` be added?

data.title: Opening VS Code by double-clicking file in File Explorer forgets previously opened files

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
If you have a mixture of saved and non-saved files open in VS Code...

- Quitting and restarting VS Code restores all the files that were previously open. Saved and non-saved. As expected.

- However, if you quit VS Code and then double-click on a text file in File Explorer, when VS Code starts it only opens the non-saved files (i.e. the "hot-saved" files) that were open previously, in addition the the new file that you double-clicked on to launch VS Code. All of the saved files that were previously open are forgotten about, and they are not restored.

I usually have a variety of text files open in VS Code and I would like the session to be restored whenever I restart VS Code, whether that is by explicitly launching VS Code from its shortcut, or by launching VS Code by double-clicking a file that it is registered for. The former works as I expect, but unfortunately the latter does not.
